stem: A 49-year-old male presented with pain over the left iliac fossa. On examination, there is abdominal rigidity and significant tenderness over the region. The most likely diagnosis is
disc:
Acute diverticulitis is inflammation/infection of a diverticulum. Patients are mostly above 45 years.

The most common presentation is abdominal pain. In addition, they may have a low-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea/constipation.

In diverticulitis, usually, the pain is in the lower-left quadrant of the abdomen (involvement of the sigmoid colon). Occasionally, the pain may be on the right side or in the suprapubic region due to the involvement of the caecum.

Approximately 25% of the patients have complications at presentation. They include
- Bowel obstruction
- Abscess/fistula
- Colonic perforation and peritonitis

Colonoscopy is not performed during the acute phase due to the risk of perforation. However, it should be performed at least after 6 weeks following the resolution to exclude underlying colorectal cancer.
